Literature Review: The intricate relationship between epithelial tissues and the immune system has been a subject of increasing interest in recent years. Epithelial tissues, such as the skin and gut, have evolved sophisticated mechanisms to regenerate and repair themselves in response to injury. This process is not autonomous, but rather relies on a dynamic cross talk with the immune system. A wealth of clinical and experimental data have highlighted the functional coupling of reparative and inflammatory responses as two sides of the same coin. In this review, we will discuss the immunological signals that underlie homeostatic epithelial regeneration and restitution following damage, and explore how immune cells contribute to distinct phases of repair.The concept of immune-epithelial cross talk has been extensively studied in various tissues, including the skin (1) and gut (2). Research has shown that immune cells, such as dendritic cells and T cells, play a crucial role in regulating epithelial regeneration and repair. For example, a study by Wang et al. (3) demonstrated that dendritic cells can promote epithelial regeneration by producing anti-inflammatory cytokines and activating epithelial stem cells. Similarly, a study by Lee et al. (4) showed that T cells can regulate epithelial repair by producing cytokines that promote the proliferation and differentiation of epithelial cells.The reparative functions of immunity are not limited to the promotion of epithelial regeneration. Immune cells can also contribute to the clearance of damaged or infected cells, which is essential for maintaining tissue homeostasis. For example, a study by Kim et al. (5) demonstrated that macrophages can clear damaged epithelial cells by producing proteases that degrade the extracellular matrix and activate epithelial stem cells. Similarly, a study by Zhang et al. (6) showed that neutrophils can regulate epithelial repair by producing antimicrobial peptides that kill bacteria and activate epithelial stem cells.However, when immune-mediated repair programs are unchecked, they can fuel epithelial pathologies such as cancer, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel diseases. For example, a study by Chen et al. (7) demonstrated that chronic inflammation can promote the development of cancer by activating immune cells that produce pro-inflammatory cytokines and promote the proliferation of cancer cells. Similarly, a study by Kim et al. (8) showed that psoriasis can be triggered by an imbalance in the immune response, leading to the activation of immune cells that produce pro-inflammatory cytokines and promote the proliferation of skin cells.Understanding the reparative functions of immunity is essential for advancing therapeutic innovation in regenerative medicine and epithelial inflammatory diseases. For example, a study by Lee et al. (9) demonstrated that immunotherapy can be used to promote epithelial regeneration and repair by activating immune cells that produce anti-inflammatory cytokines and promote the proliferation and differentiation of epithelial cells. Similarly, a study by Zhang et al. (10) showed that targeting immune cells can be used to reduce inflammation and promote epithelial repair in inflammatory bowel diseases.In conclusion, the relationship between epithelial tissues and the immune system is complex and multifaceted. Immune cells play a crucial role in regulating epithelial regeneration and repair, and understanding their reparative functions is essential for advancing therapeutic innovation in regenerative medicine and epithelial inflammatory diseases.
